questions.text: A farmer having trauma on lower limb following which a cauliflower like growth develops. Biopsy findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A farmer having trauma on lower limb following which a cauliflower like growth - points to subcutaneous mycoses.

Biopsy shows copper penny bodies

Diagnosis : chromoblastomycosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 32, Page 76

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Impetigo is a common infection of the superficial layers of the epidermis that is highly contagious and most commonly caused by gram-positive bacteria.

Nonbullous impetigo is caused by S aureus and Group A beta-hemolytic Strep (GABHS).

Nonbullous impetigo often starts as a vesicle or a pustule, ruptures after which the purulent exudate forms the characteristic golden yellow honey-colored crust. An erythematous base is also present.

MC site: face

questions.text: Identify the following lines
questions.solution:
Langer's lines/Relaxed skin tension lines/cleavage lines, are topological lines drawn on a map of the human body.

They are parallel to the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis, and generally perpendicular to the underlying muscle fibers.

Incisions made parallel to Langer's lines heal better and produce less scarring than those that cut across.

Conversely, incisions perpendicular to Langer's lines have a tendency to gape and heal with hypertrophic/keloid scars.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 20, page 2

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient of cervical carcinoma presents with excessive hair loss 2-3 weeks after starting chemotherapy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anagen effluvium is a form of nonscarring alopecia commonly associated with chemotherapy. In this disorder, affected anagen hairs suffer a toxic or inflammatory insult, resulting in fracture of the hair shaft.

Shedding usually takes place within 14 days of administration of the offending drug, however, in many instances it is reversible, with hair regrowth occurring upon discontinuation of the offending agent.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter89, Page 48

choices.text: Androgens are related to the pathogenesis
Obesity and smoking are the 2 main factors associated with it
IL-17 inhibitors like secukinumab can be used in treatment
It is a disease of the sebaceous glands

questions.text: A patient presents recurrent abscesses with tract formation and scars in the groin region. Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), also called acne inversus, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition with lesions including deep-seated nodules and abscesses, draining tracts, and fibrotic scars.

These lesions most commonly occur in intertriginous areas and areas rich in apocrine glands - axillary, groin, perianal, perineal, and inframammary locations.

Environmental and behavioral factors also contribute - Obesity, Smoking, Metabolic syndrome and hormonal changes leading to relative androgen excess, all of which are associated with HS.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 113, Page 21

choices.text: Occurs in patients with lepromatous leprosy
May anytime during the duration of disease
Presents as painful nodules on limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Type 2 Lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Sudden changes in immune-mediated response to Mycobacterium leprae antigen are referred to as leprosy reactions. The reactions manifest as acute inflammatory episodes

Leprosy reactions can occur at any time before, during, or after the treatment.

Type 2 reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) occurs in patients with high bacilli load as in patients with LL leprosy)

This is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction associated with the deposition of immunocomplexes produced by binding of antigens released by the destruction of bacilli with antibodies

This reaction can involve multiple organs and systems.

Skin lesions - multiple, bilateral, erythematous, firm, painful, subcutaneous nodules - Erythema nodosum Leprosum (ENL) that are distributed symmetrically.

General symptoms such as fever, weakness, edema, myalgia-arthralgia,

Systemic - Iridocyclitis, episcleritis, orchitis, liver, or kidney damage can be observed.

Neuritis, painful enlarged nerves and nerve function impairment may occur

Treatment, continue MBMDT, NSAIDS, High dose oral steroids (treatment of choice). Other drugs -clofazamine, pentoxifylline, and thalidomide are used in the treatment

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 28, page 12

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of a solitary erythematous oval lesion with central clearing, giving a bull's eye appearance. The rash has been increasing in size since its appearance. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erythema migrans is an early localized form of Lyme disease. It typically develops between 5-7 days following a tick bite and may present with symptoms like burning, itching, or may be asymptomatic. The classic appearance is an erythematous oval lesion with central clearing, giving it the characteristic "bull's eye" look. The rash tends to expand for a few days, with possible concentric rings and central clearing. Some patients may experience recurrent episodes, and multiple lesions are not uncommon.

Option B: Erythema annulare (also known as gyrate erythema) is characterized by annular, polycyclic, erythematous plaques with scaling behind the advancing edge. It is most commonly seen on the buttocks, thighs, and upper arms.

Option C: Erythema multiforme typically presents with macular, papular, or urticarial lesions as well as the classic acral iris or target lesions. These target lesions are smaller than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and consist of three distinct zones:

  1. Central zone of purpura,
  2. Zone of edema,
  3. Zone of erythema.

These lesions are commonly found on the dorsum of the hands, palms, wrists, feet, and extensor aspects. Erythema multiforme usually develops over a few days and resolves in 2-3 weeks, often associated with herpes simplex infection.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No.15.

choices.text: 5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours
1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours

questions.text: 1-year-old infant presents to the clinic with itchy exudative skin lesions shown below. Which medication should be prescribed, and how should it be administered?
questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation is consistent with scabies.
  • To treat scabies, 5% permethrin cream should be applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours.
  • Mucosal sites should be avoided when applying topical permethrin.
  • Close contacts of patients with scabies should also be treated.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 34, Page 44

questions.text: A patient presents with asymptomatic rash on the body along with palmoplantar lesions as shown. What can be seen during genital examination ?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the patient - asymptomatic rash and coppery brown palmoplantar lesions point to diagnosis of Secondary syphilis.

Genital examination in such a patient can show presence of condyloma lata. These are highly infectious, flat-topped, well-demarcated hypertrophic papules or plaques, which often present in intertriginous areas, such as the genitals and anus. CL are usually diagnosed by their characteristic physical appearance confirmed by darkfield microscopy and/or skin biopsy along with serological tests.

Other options

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 29, page 13

questions.text: A hypertensive patient was started on a medication by his physician. A few weeks later, he developed shallow skin erosions with crust formation. There is no involvement of the scalp or mucous membranes. A clinical sign as shown in image is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is pemphigus foliaceus, which is an autoimmune disorder similar to pemphigus vulgaris.
  • It can occur after exposure to a group of drugs containing a thiol group such as captopril or enalapril.
  • It is seen in myasthenia gravis, thymoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Endemic pemphigus foliaceus often is seen in central and southwestern Brazil and Colombia. It is not common in Asia.
  • DSG1 is present in foliaceous and DSG1 and 3 both are present in vulgaris

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition chapter 50, page 5

questions.text: A patient presents with itchy papulovesicular lesions on the shoulder, back, arms and legs. The DIF results showed positivity for IgA deposits. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
IgA deposits in dermis are seen in the following conditions:

  1. Granular deposits (at tips of dermal papilla) → Dermatitis Herpetiformis (option A)
  2. Linear deposits → CBDC and Linear IgA dermatoses of Adults (option B).

Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Associated with:

  1. Subclinical gluten sensitive enteropathy.
  2. HLA - B8/DRw3 & HLA DQW2
  3. IgA autoantibodies against epidermal transglutaminase & granular deposits of IgA in papillary dermis.
  4. C/F - Intensely pruritic, papulovesicular lesions, symmetrically distributed over extensor surfaces (i.e. elbows, knees, buttocks, back scalp & posterior neck)
  5. Age: 2nd - 4th decades
  6. HPE: Subepidermal blister with neutrophilic papillary tip abcesses.
  7. DIF - granular deposits of IgA along the basement membrane zone.
  8. IgA deposits in skin are unaffected by control of disease with medication dapsone; but decrease or disappear in patients maintained on long periods on a strict gluten - free diet.
  9. Herpes Gestation(option C)
    • Autoimmune vesiculobullous disorder seen in pregnancy
    • Linear IgG deposits in BMZ (base membrane zone)
  10. Bullous Pemphigoid (option D):
    • Linear IgG deposits in BMZ (base membrane zone)

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 50, Page 53

questions.text: What is the finding shown pointed in the image ?
questions.solution:
Oil drop or salmon patch of the nail bed - This lesion is a translucent, yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil beneath the nail plate. This patch is the most diagnostic sign of nail psoriasis.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35, page 13

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with lesions in oral cavity as shown below. His proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucosal involvement affects over half of all LP patients and frequently is the sole presenting sign.

It is most commonly seen in the mouth but can be found on the lips, esophagus, glans penis, vulva, or vagina.

Two main subtypes of oral LP exist: reticular, erosive

Reticular is the most common form and presents as asymptomatic white, lacy lines often seen on the bilateral buccal mucosa.

The erosive form is commonly associated with a burning pain exacerbated by hot or spicy foods. A very low risk (~1% of oral SCC).

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 37, page 5

questions.text: A 22 year old male developed pigmentation over upper chest for the last 2 years as shown in image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
BM is considered to be a benign, late-onset type of epidermal nevus.

Associated features like peri pubertal development, male preponderance, hypertrichosis, and acneiform lesions suggest a role for androgens. An increase in the number of androgen receptors has been reported

The most common sites involved are the shoulder, scapular area, and the upper arms

BM presents as a well-defined, unilateral, hyperpigmented tan or brown patch which increases in size, gradually often developing into a geographic pattern.

Significant hair growth over the lesions is usually seen

Acneiform lesions may develop over the affected area

Treatment:- As Becker's nevus is considered a benign lesion, treatment is generally not necessary except for cosmetic purposes. Q switched ND YAG laser can be used

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 75, page 15

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain for which NSAIDS were taken, now presents with brownish pigmentation on the nose as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chikungunya fever is an acute febrile illness caused by arboviridae, characterized by debilitating polyarthralgia and other constitutional symptoms. NSAIDS form an important part of management for the body ache and arthralgias.

Cutaneous manifestations are seen in a lot of patients.

The striking post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation over the centrofacial area (chik sign/brownie-nose) may even persist upto 6 months.

The postulated cause of hyperpigmentation may be attributed to increased intra epidermal melanin dispersion or retention triggered by chikungunya fever.

The presence of 'chik sign' may be a useful marker for retrospective diagnosis of chikungunya fever.

Also seen in dengue fever.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 88, page 11

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with light brown macules over the cheeks since past 5 years. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Melasma is common, acquired, circumscribed pigmentation in sun-exposed skin.
  • It presents as symmetric, hyperpigmented macules having irregular, serrated borders.
  • The most common locations are the sun-exposed areas like cheeks, upper lips, the chin, and the forehead, but other may also occasionally be involved.
  • The three major patterns of pigmentation in melasma are centrofacial (cheeks, forehead, upper lip, and nose), malar (cheeks and nose), and mandibular (mandibular area of cheeks).
  • Precipitating factors for melasma to develop are pregnancy, OC pills and UV light.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 88, page 11

questions.text: A female has itchy rash on forehead. The chemical responsible is
questions.solution:
The sticker bindis are made up of circular discs of polyvinylchloride (PVC) and the adhesive material contains para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP)

This chemical causes depigmentation through their melanocytotoxic effect leading to chemical leucoderma.

And this is also an allergen implicated in causation of contact dermatitis due to bindi - bindi dermatitis

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition, chapter 128, page 19

questions.text: A six-year-old child with a history of atopic dermatitis presents to the clinic for evaluation. Some asymptomatic lesions are noticed on extensor surfaces of the proximal upper and lower extremities. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Keratosis pilaris is multifactorial and innocuous, affecting the extensor surfaces of the proximal extremities.
  • KP first appears in early childhood and progresses, becoming most extensive during the second decade of life.
  • Associated with Atopic dermatitis, ichthyosis vulgaris.
  • Follicular papules on the extensors. Antenna sign seen

Phrynoderma - dry lichenoid follicular papules on dry skin on elbows/knees, seen in Vitamin A, B, E, K deficiency

Scurvy - Vitamin C deficiency, commonly called scurvy, - corkscrew hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, and gingival bleeding.

Corkscrew strands, characterized by twisted or coiled hair shafts, result from impaired collagen synthesis and are considered pathognomonic for scurvy.

Perifollicular hemorrhages are often localized to the lower extremities, as capillary fragility cannot withstand gravity-dependent hydrostatic pressure. This can lead to a condition known as "woody edema".

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 41, page 3

questions.text: A farmer develops lesions over V area of the chest, Arms, face associated with itching. You did a test to confirm the diagnosis. When is the reading taken ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis is made by patch testing.

Allergen in the patch test can be applied to normal skin, usually on the upper back where the tests are least likely to be disturbed.

The diagnosis is Airborne contact dermatitis. Patch test reading is done at 48 and 96 hours.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition, chapter 128, page 128.64

questions.text: A patient presents with rashes all over body with erosions of the lips and other mucosa since 2 days. What can be the triggering factor?
questions.solution:
• Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a potentially life-threatening dermatologic disorder characterized by widespread (> 30% BSA), erythema, necrosis, and bullous detachment of the epidermis and mucous membranes, resulting in exfoliation.
  • Mucous membrane involvement can result in gastrointestinal hemorrhage, respiratory failure, ocular abnormalities, and genitourinary complications.
  • TEN is most commonly drug-induced - antibiotics (sulfonamides), antiepileptic drugs (Phenobarbital, Phenytoin), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), ampicillin, allopurinol, and the antiretroviral drugs (nevirapine, abacavir).
  • The mainstay of treatment is supportive care until the epithelium regenerates.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 119, page 10

questions.text: Lymphocytic micro-abscess as shown below, is a histological feature of-
questions.solution:
In mycosis fungoides, T cells characteristically form bandlike aggregates within the superficial dermis and invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters (Pautrier microabscesses).

Psoriasis - Neutrophilic abscesses (Munro - S.corneum, Kogoj spongiform pustules - S.Spinosum )

Dermatitis herpetiformis - Neutrophilic papillary tip abscesses

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 140, page 140.3

questions.text: A 70 year old man presented with lesion on the face, with history of bleeding when he scratches the lesion. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
A shiny well-ill defined plaque with rolled up borders and a central erosion which may bleed on touch/scratching - BCC

Most common skin malignancy

Due to sun exposure

No premalignant lesion

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 141, page 141.8

questions.text:
A 15 year old girl presents with reddish papules on the face. Which of the following findings may be noted on further examination and investigations.
1. Lisch nodule
2. Renal Cortical Cyst
3. Rhabdomyoma of heart and lung
4. Neurofibromas
5. Koenon tumor
questions.solution:
The image depicts - adenoma sebaceoum, also called as facial angiofibromas. These are seen in tuberous sclerosis

Manifestation of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Retinal & optic nerve hamartomas
  • Achromic retinal patches
  • Involvement of skull, spine and pelvis
  • Dental pits
  • Tumors of heart (rhabdomyomas)

Periungual fibromas, also called as koenons tumors

Lisch nodules and neurofibromas are seen in Neurofibromatoses type 1

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 80, page 11

questions.text: A 7 years old child presents with freckles, telangiectatic spots, photosensitivity, microcephaly. Sibling also suffers from similar symptoms. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genodermatosis that results due to mutations in nucleotide excision repair.

The nucleotide excision repair system is capable of removing ultraviolet-induced damage to DNA, such as pyrimidine dimers and pyrimidines 6-4 pyrimidones. The progression of xeroderma pigmentosum is due to the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage

All patients with xeroderma pigmentosum will present with skin changes secondary to severe sun sensitivity. Patients may also present with oral, ophthalmologic, and/or neurologic manifestations of the disease.

The condition characteristically demonstrates severe photosensitivity, skin pigmentary changes, malignant tumor development, and occasionally progressive neurologic degeneration.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 78, page 1

questions.text: The following clinical picture is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Pellagra is a nutritional disorder caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to systemic disease with clinical manifestations from the skin, gastrointestinal tract and the nervous system.
  • The pellagra syndrome has historically been characterized by the 4 D's: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia leading to Death.
  • The characteristic skin rash has a typical photosensitive distribution with welldefined borders, and is mostly observed on the face, the neck - forming the so-called Casal's necklace-, the dorsa of the hands and the extensor surface of the forearms.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement - intractable diarrhea, stomatitis and glossitis,
  • Neurocognitive impairment - apathy, memory loss (dementia).
  • Niacin deficiency should especially be suspected in - corn/maize eaters, chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, malabsorption, hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis, drugs like isoniazid, ethionamide, 6-mercaptopurine and estrogens, carcinoid syndrome.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition, chapter 63, page 15
